0.52.text: Planet Earth is the home of every lifeform,

2.52.text: known to us, in the universe.

5.12.text: Its age is about 1/3 of the age of the universe

9.58.text: It is a thing of beauty.

11.80.text: a slightly squashed fair with a heavy metal core,

15.80.text: wrapped in a thin sliver of sweet air to breathe,

23.04.text: fresh water rivers, streams, lakes and aquifers,

26.12.text: orbiting a star which warms us,

30.40.text: But how did our home come in to existence,

43.78.text: Earth was created from the remnants of dead stars,

46.12.text: that collected in a giant, dirty gas cloud.

49.36.text: The gas cloud became denser in its center,

56.26.text: and building larger and larger objects,

58.34.text: until they form the objects we call "Planets" today.

61.96.text: This process took 10 to 20 million years,

64.36.text: and is still not very well understood.

67.16.text: At about this time, when the solar system was young and chaotic,

70.22.text: a giant object, about as big as Mars,

76.28.text: and if the object had been more massive,

80.66.text: Materials from Earth were smashed out into orbit,

84.18.text: which is the biggest satellite in relation to its planet in the solar system.

88.44.text: At this time, Earth was a hot hell,

96.08.text: But something was about to change drastically.

100.70.text: Water from the inside of the Earth

102.70.text: wandered to the surface and rained down on Earth,

105.50.text: only to vaporize again and become clouds.

108.56.text: Millions of asteroids brought more and more water to our planet.

112.68.text: All the water on Earth has about this volume compared to Earth.

118.18.text: the surface of Earth is 71% water,

128.48.text: The Fresh water is 69% ice and snow,

133.46.text: and only about 1% make up the remaining ground waters.

137.68.text: But even this small part is mostly frozen.

140.62.text: Only a tiny part of our water is actually lakes and rivers.

143.84.text: and an even tinier part is bound in living things.

147.88.text: So, gradually the Earth cooled down,

150.24.text: and the surface formed a thin crust.

152.24.text: But inside the earth, hot rock continue to swirl about,

155.72.text: moving the crust from below and breaking it apart.

163.80.text: We'll make a whole video about it in the future.

167.02.text: let's just say that the crust of Earth consisted of

169.20.text: separate giant plates that move around.

171.58.text: As they meet, they crumble, and create mighty mountains.

175.50.text: violently plunge back down, deeper into Earth,

180.16.text: That's the way the highest place on Earth was formed: Mt.Everest,

183.08.text: and the deepest: the Mariana Trench.

187.20.text: Earth's mountains and trenches are mighty indeed,

190.14.text: but when you look at the Earth in cross-section,

192.34.text: you can see how tiny they actually are.

195.08.text: The part we stand on is the crust,

198.76.text: though it can vary between 5 and 70 kilometers

202.50.text: the deepest hole ever drilled by man

207.06.text: After the crust, comes the mantle.

213.62.text: The mantle consists of the upper mantle, and the lower mantle.

217.32.text: The upper mantle has different regions, too.

219.68.text: It's upper part, which is viscous and carries the crust,

226.44.text: which consists of less mobile, mostly solid material.

230.42.text: The lower mantle reaches deep down to the outer core of Earth.

234.18.text: Earth's outer core is a liquid layer of iron and nickel,

246.26.text: And in the center, is the inner core.

250.56.text: a ball made of an iron-nickel alloy.

252.80.text: with a radius of about 1,200 kilometers.

255.66.text: 70% of the size of the moon,

257.50.text: and about the temperature of the surface of the Sun.

261.94.text: at an estimated rate of about 1mm/year.

267.44.text: this small layer of crystallized melt products of former molten mantle,

278.04.text: that diverts high energy particles coming from the Sun and other sources,

283.42.text: with comparatively little radiation impact on Earth.

288.58.text: Actually, we don't really know a terrible lot about that.

291.96.text: We know, it has something to do with the core of Earth.

296.06.text: large electrical currents flow in complicated patterns.

301.32.text: that sort of stabilizes itself according to the laws of electrodynamics.

305.54.text: This entire system is called the "Dynamo."

308.46.text: But, don't let us fool you into thinking we have it all figured out.

314.98.text: what about the airy stuff that surrounds us?

319.00.text: dry air consists mostly of Nitrogen,

324.08.text: a variable mount of water vapor,

325.84.text: and small amounts of other gases.

328.36.text: Humans are very dependent on the lowest layer of the atmosphere:

331.74.text: the Troposphere - Where the weather is.

338.18.text: which is where the ozone layer protects us

340.18.text: from the sun's most aggressive type of light.

342.92.text: Above that is the Mesosphere - the coolest place on Earth,

350.58.text: At about 80 kilometers up, the Thermosphere starts.

354.00.text: The transition to space is a fluent one, without clear borders.

357.36.text: but humans decided that space starts here.

360.52.text: At about 100 kilometers, Earth stops, and space begins,

363.74.text: though the atmosphere extends a bit further.

366.66.text: In this region, we find the Ionosphere,

372.72.text: and the outermost layer is the Exosphere,

378.08.text: It merges fluently with outer space,

380.22.text: where there's no atmosphere at all.

382.42.text: The atoms and molecules in this area are so far apart,

385.46.text: that they can travel hundreds of kilometers

392.38.text: have only been around for 200,000 years.

401.98.text: living in a thin, moist layer on a small, wet rock.

408.04.text: It is the product of the universe's deepest workings,

410.92.text: the result of a constant process of creation and destruction,

414.98.text: happening all of the universe, all the time,

419.28.text: the laws of the universe and random events,
